content.question: A solid cylinder with known radius is rolling while slipping along a horizontal surface, as shown. The center of mass of the cylinder is moving to the right and slowing down, and the cylinder is rotating in a counterclockwise direction. At the instant shown, the speed of the center of mass of the cylinder is <math alttext="v sub center of mass" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>cm</mtext></msub></math> and the angular speed of the cylinder is <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ω</mi></math>. Can the relationship between <math alttext="v sub center of mass" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>cm</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ω</mi></math> be determined? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because <math alttext="v sub center of mass equals r omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>cm</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>r</mi><mi>ω</mi></mstyle></math>.

Yes, because the linear acceleration of the center of mass is related to the angular acceleration by <math alttext="a sub center of mass equals r alpha" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>a</mi><mtext>cm</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>r</mi><mi>α</mi></mstyle></math>.
No, because the friction force dissipates an unknown amount of energy from the cylinder-surface system.
No, because when an object is slipping, the motion of the center of mass and the rotational motion of the object are not related.

content.answer: No, because when an object is slipping, the motion of the center of mass and the rotational motion of the object are not related.
